instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is 3V3_S0SW_LCD? 3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. This is necessary to get an image on the screen.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No image or backlight - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hey!

I got this Macbook I’m working on. A Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) from 2018. It has no image – or backlight for that matter.

No history of liquid spills or anything. It's fully functional on external monitor - and the webcam works.. But it doesn't seem like the internal display is even detected in the settings.

The backlight has been lighting up a few times when entering recovery-mode.

I tested the panel on another Macbook, and the display worked perfectly. So, I know it’s well and working.

I get 0 volts on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>. Tried diode-mode on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> and got a reading of about 1950. I’m not I entirely sure what that tells me.

I really can’t figure out what the problem is. Can’t seem to find any defect components or anything.

All the best

-R

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No image or backlight - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Check presence of <SIGNAL>3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL>, when LCD is connected.
Don't waste time searching for backlight, if no image yet.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No image or backlight - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Thank you sir!

I get 3.3V on both <SIGNAL>3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> when LCD is connected.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No image or backlight - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground on pins 1 & 3 of J8500.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No image or backlight - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground on pins 1 & 3 of J8500.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No image or backlight - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No image or backlight - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
For diode mode readings, there is big difference.
That points to damaged <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>; change it.
Be sure no corrosion sign on that side of J8500.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No image or backlight - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Thank you! I'll try changing the <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> and get back with the result.
